clinical_study.brief_title: The Use of FLOSEAL to Reduce Bleeding in Total Knee Replacement Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: The Role of a Topical Hemostatic Agent in Reducing Blood Loss in Unilateral Total Knee Arthroplasty

lead_sponsor.agency: Hospital for Special Surgery, New York

clinical_study.source: Hospital for Special Surgery, New York

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if the agent, Floseal, can decrease the amount of blood patients lose after total knee replacement (TKR) surgery. If this product can be found to have an effect on bleeding, it may potentially reduce the problems associated with bleeding after knee replacement surgery such as pain, stiffness, and the need to have a blood transfusion. The subject's overall participation will be over a period of 6 weeks.

study_design_info.masking: Double Blind (Participant, Care Provider, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Fall in post-operative hemoglobin and hematocrit. Data will be collected from laboratory tests
primary_outcome.time_frame: before surgery and the first and second days after surgery

primary_outcome.measure: Drain output in milliliters at 24 hours. This will be recorded from the time the drain was inserted.
Transfusion requirements - The total number of units, along with the individual number of autologous and homologous units required for each patient will be recorded.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 days after surgery, 6 weeks after surgery
3 days after surgery, 6 weeks after surgery

arm_group.description: 2 vials of Floseal applied once at the end of surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Single Knee replacement for arthritis of the knee
Exclusion Criteria:
- No inflammatory arthritis (ie. Rheumatoid arthritis)
- No allergies to cow meat (bovine allergies
- No history of bleeding disorders

clinical_study.keyword: To decrease blood loss during knee surgery
